text:
BRIAN KENNY: Welcome to
Managing Through Crisis,

the webcast featuring
faculty from Harvard Business

School sharing insights for
managers on how to navigate
through the COVID-19 crisis.

Today, we're going to
talk about supply chain.

Supply chains not usually the
most trendy topic in business--
until it is.

The pandemic put a spotlight
on supply chain issues

early on, as panic-stricken
consumers cleared

store shelves of
pretty much everything,

uncertain when supplies
would be replenished.
Were those concerns justified?

And what does the future hold
with regard to supply chains?

Today, we're fortunate to have
Professor Willy Shee joining
us.

Willy is an expert in
manufacturing and product

development, and of
course, supply chain.

And more recently,
he's become a sought

after expert on toilet
paper, of all things.

Willy, thanks so much
for joining me today.

WILLY SHEE: Well, thank
you for having me, Brian.

BRIAN KENNY: I think as we
were talking just now before we

got started here,
people are really

thirsting for
information about how

they can think about
managing through this thing,

both on a personal and
professional level.

And supply chain is
one of those things

that I think impacts
people in both ways.

They're consumers, but
they're also managers.

And they're interested
in making sure

that they can provide for
whatever their needs are, too,
as consumers.

So I think there'll
be a lot of interest
in what you have to say today.

But I'm going to ask you to
start by talking about toilet
paper of all things.

You had this article
in Forbes on March 4th.

It turned out to be
a smash hit for you.

But maybe you can
just tell us, why

was toilet paper such
a focal point early on?

WILLY SHEE: Well, Brian, what
happened with toilet paper is,

first of all, what
we're seeing is a very
unusual time in the world.

We're seeing a supply shock
for things coming out of China

starting in February, then
coupled with the demand shock,
OK.

And toilet paper was one
of those manifestations.

Now what happened is I
wrote this piece in Forbes

about toilet paper
because I heard

from a former colleague of
mine in Australia about how

people were hoarding toilet
paper and she couldn't get any.

And I had heard about
these shortages in Japan
and then Hong Kong.

And I said, well, OK, so
this is actually a useful way

to teach people
about supply chain.
So I wrote this column.

Because I said,
well, first of all,

toilet paper is a product
that everybody understands.
We use it, we understand it.

And we also understand
that demand is flat, right?

There's not a season where
you use more toilet paper.

Or there are not occasions
where you use more toilet paper.

Right, therefore, if
you think about what

the supply chain for toilet
paper should look like,
it's very voluminous, right?

but I need to move
it on a regular basis

from the factories
into the retail stores.

And by and large, toilet
paper, since it's bulky

and it doesn't cost a lot,
it has a low value density.

So we think of it as not
particularly tradable.

It's not like I'm going to
import toilet paper from China.

By and large, I'm going to
make it within a region.

Like for North America, the US
is self-sufficient in toilet
paper.

China is self-sufficient
in toilet paper.

Europe is self-sufficient
in toilet paper.

Right, so it's that
nice, simple example.

And what it highlights
is, how much resiliency

do manufacturers
and the supply chain
have to sudden spikes in demand?

OK, so, for example,
the answer is,

since I know toilet paper
demand is going to be very flat,

I'm not going to have a
lot of surge capacity.

OK, now, it turns out the
demand shifted a little bit.

Because people weren't
using it in schools like us

or in offices or hotels
and travel companies.

But that's a
different supply chain

for that commercial
industrial type toilet paper.

OK, so then, you don't
need a lot of demand surge

to throw things
way out of whack.

So it exemplifies some of
the crises we're seeing.

Now, that also extends
to, for example,
things like masks, N95 masks.
Personal protective equipment.

Because in that case, we've
seen manufacturers in the US
like 3M make some.

A lot of people
make it in China.

And a lot of the personal
protective equipment

is manufactured in China,
because it's cheaper, OK?

And we've seen a
lot of shortages,

and people are
saying, well, how come

the US can't make more masks and
personal protective equipment?

And that starts to
expose what some

of the realities of
manufacturing and supply chains

are, which is, I don't have a
lot of surge capacity, right?

Because if I have
idle plant capacity,

my investors are
going to penalize me

or the analysts are
going to penalize me.

It's like, oh, you're running
a factory at 50% capacity?

Why do you have all
that idle capacity?

Because all of that goes
into the cost equation.

OK, now, I heard one number
that the demand for masks
has surged 20x, right?

Nobody is going to have
the capacity for that.

So now what we're
seeing is we're

seeing a lot of stress
in the supply chain.

So that's a picture
of what's going on.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

I don't want to assume that
everybody who's watching this

understands the definition
of supply chains.

So let me just ask
you quickly, what

is your 30-second definition
of what a supply chain is?

WILLY SHEE: Well, for
me, the supply chain

is the series of manufacturers
who will make my product

and the logistics links
that connect them.

OK, and so, it's very
much like a chain.

I might buy a product
from a retailer.

Maybe I'll buy it
from Amazon, OK,

or maybe I'll buy it from
the local grocery store.

OK, that retailer,
for example, will

have a supply chain that
supplies those products
behind it.

So it'll have a
manufacturer connected
through a distribution center.

And then that
manufacturer may also

use other suppliers who we
refer to as tiers on the supply
chain.

OK, so the product
manufacturer may

have a set of suppliers
who might be what we
would call tier one suppliers.

OK, those suppliers, in
turn, might have others.

Right, so you think of it as
a long chain of manufacturers

connected by logistics
links, which bring together

all the raw materials, assemble
them into finished products,

and deliver them to
your point of purchase.

BRIAN KENNY: Great,
that's very helpful.

And we had some great questions
sent in by our viewers.

So I want to get right to those,
because if people are thinking
a lot about this, actually.
WILLY SHEE: For sure.

BRIAN KENNY: One of them had to
do with the economics of supply

chains and how the pandemic
impacts the economics of supply
chains around the world.

WILLY SHEE: One of the things
that this pandemic has exposed

is how globalized most
supply chains are.

So, for example, we all know
with things like smartphones

and computers that many of
the final assembly operations

actually happen in
China or in Asia.

And a lot of the components
are drawn from China, East Asia
as well.

All of those come
together in China
and they're shipped over to us.

What people haven't
really paid attention to

is how many other products have
some link in that supply chain
that goes through China.

So, for example, blood
oxygenators or things

like active pharmaceutical
ingredients,

which is something that has
gotten a lot of attention
recently.

A lot of generic
pharmaceuticals actually

are manufactured
in India using what

are called active pharmaceutical
ingredients, which come out
of China.

Right, so now you
can think of a chain

where that ibuprofen that you
pick up in the grocery store

actually had chemical compounds
that come out of China,

were shipped to India where they
formulated them into ibuprofen.

And then they shipped them to
distributors around the world.

And then eventually, they
make it into the drug store.
So I think this shock--

OK, I mentioned earlier
the supply shock.

The supply shock came
when China shut down.

Right, China was the first one
to have this coronavirus impact
in Hubei province in Wuhan.

OK, and they basically shut
down the country for an extended
Lunar New Year break.

OK, normally, the Lunar
New Year would have
started around January 25th.

But what they did is
extended the break.

Now, one of the reasons we
didn't see a lot of impact

for a while is
because many companies

who source materials
and products from China

could anticipate this
Lunar New Year break.

And so they know,
oh, OK, everybody's

going to shut down for a week
starting around January 25th.

And by the way, the last
shipments coming out of China
would leave around January 25th.

And about anywhere from
30 to 40 days later,

you would see that
last shipment arrive

either on the East Coast of the
US or in Europe or somewhere
like that.

OK, so there was
this delayed impact.

OK, then, the Lunar New
Year break was extended

and many factories
really didn't get
going again until mid March.

So now there was this gap in
terms of product supply, OK.

And we often think of
this delayed reaction

through a supply chain
as a bullwhip effect.

It's like just when I
needed more from you guys,

you're not shipping
anymore, right?
And so I'm going to order more.

Right, so what happened
is we had this shortfall

at the end of
February where people

were putting in emergency
orders and giving the expedited
shipments and stuff like that.
OK.

And so then, as soon as
China got back to work,

they started filling all those
back orders just at a time

when economies in the US and
Europe started to shut down.

So we had a supply shock
then collide with a demand

shock, where people
stopped buying furniture,
clothing, shoes--

anything outside of medical
supplies and groceries.

Right, so we had this rather
unique combination of supply

shock meets demand shock,
and it made a horrible mess.

BRIAN KENNY: So part
of what you're saying

is pretty alarming in the
sense that our supply chain
is global in nature.

We are all connected
through this global series,

sets of providers and
shippers and logistics.

Does this mean we
need to be rethinking

the global nature
of the supply chain

and going back to much
more of a supply chain,

for instance in the
US, where we are making
and buying everything locally?

WILLY SHEE: Well, there
are two questions really
embedded in that.

OK, the first one is
one of resilience.

Right, how resilient am I to
disruptions that come along?

OK, now, admittedly,
this disruption

has been really quite
massive in terms

of all the other
disruptions that we've
seen in the last century.

Right, because, basically,
we have put the US economy
into a medically induced coma.
In Europe as well, right?
So that's a major shock.

Now the first question
is resilience.

To the extent that
I am dependent

on this dispersed
supply chain, how good

am I at withstanding
those shocks?

Now, one of the
things you can do

is you can have
strategic inventory.

Right, you can have
stockpiles of things

that you might want to have
in case I'm cut off, right?

I think what has happened is
over especially the last 20

years, where we've seen
big leaps in the efficiency

and lower cost of
international shipping,

primarily through
container ships,
but also through air cargo.

And this efficient, dependable
transportation logistics

between the links
of the supply chain

has lulled everybody
into thinking, well, gee,

I can build a supply chain
with minimal inventory.
safety stock.

Oftentimes we talk about
safety stock in case I run out.

So the first thing that
has been disproven by what
we are experiencing now.

And one way you can solve
that is you can say,
I want to diversify my supplies.

I want to maybe not be quite so
dependent on one country or one
region of the world.

And that might be a push
back to being more regional.

And I think we will
see some of that, OK?

The second issue
that's embedded in that

is, do we want to be more
self-sufficient or at least
regionally more self-sufficient?

And you'll see a lot of people
jumping on the globalization

bandwagon saying, OK, this
is the end of globalization,

we really don't want to be
dependent on other countries
so much anymore.

I would say, be careful
when you ask for that, OK?

Because the world is remarkably
interdependent right now.

And that has
benefited everybody.

If you look at the
cornucopia of products

that we are able
to buy at low cost,

it's because we trade
with so many people

around the world
who can specialize
in doing different things.

That's the foundation
of the whole Ricardian
notion of trade.

OK, and so if you talk about,
I want to regionalize more,

we're necessarily going to have
to spend more for our products,
maybe have less variety.

Because not every country
is capable of providing

that wealth, that range
of products, by itself.

OK, the US is more capable
than a lot of countries.

But you would be
surprised how many things

we are dependent
on not only China,

OK, but European countries,
South Africa, Canada, Mexico.

Lots of other places
for those products.

And by the way, they're
dependent on us as well.

BRIAN KENNY: So we had
one of our viewers asked

a question about GM and their
move to make ventilators.

And I have the
same thought, which

is, how does a company that
makes cars all of a sudden

turn on a dime and
make ventilators?

Where do they get the parts,
the expertise, and the skill
to do something like that?
WILLY SHEE: Yes.

Well, when I first heard that, I
was a little skeptical as well.

Right, because when you think
about the Defense Procurement

Act and when it was invoked
during World War II,

I don't want to
minimize the effort,

but things were a little
simpler in those days, OK,

and ventilators are
fairly complex products
that require FDA certification.

Now, what is very
interesting to me

about this is if you look at,
for example, GM as an example,

they converted a factory
that wasn't being used.

I think it was in
Kokomo, Indiana.

It was probably a
former Delco factory

or something that made small
subsystems or components.

They partnered with Ventec,
which is a company that has--

had a design, right,
had an existing design.

And it's like, how
do we scale larger?

Right, so I think GM did not
behave in a crazy fashion here.

Right, I mean, , there were some
of our leaders in government

who said, oh, you can make
cars, you can make ventilators.

Right, GM actually
recognized that they

can't do a lot of
those things, but they

do know what they can do
is help on procurement.

They could provide labor,
they could provide a building
and things like that.

So what I found really very
gratifying is the crisis has

unfrozen how a lot of people
think about what they can
and cannot do.

Right, so it's brought
on a new flexibility
to work very differently.

And actually,
managers should think

about that, because
it's like, why does it

take a crisis for me to
unfreeze my organization
and be able to do new things?

It's like, that's
actually very instructive.

Right, because that actually
means when the crisis passes,

I should also think about my
other capabilities that way
as well.

Which is, it's like, I
could really do new things.

So I think they've taken
a pretty good approach.
But it's a hard problem, right?

Because you want a product
that is certified safe
for hospital use.

This is not like taking
the HVAC system from a car

and then running
it to your lungs.
OK, it has to be FDA certified.

But at the same
time, we've also seen

this unfreezing apply
to the FDA as well,

who has relaxed some of the
certification requirements
for those production facilities.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

I want to go back to the
discussion we had a moment ago
about globalization.

I'm wondering, we had a
viewer write in and ask about,
how do you get--

how can consumers get
products if stores are closed,

or how can you get consumers
feeling comfortable

going back into local brick
and mortar establishments?

So my question is,
do you see this--

we've heard a lot about
farm to table restaurants,

for instance, in the
past five or six years.
That's become pretty popular.

There does seem to be, on
the one hand, this movement

towards locally made, locally
grown products and services.

Is this an opportunity
for that kind of provider
to thrive in the absence of--

or with interruptions to
the global supply chain?

WILLY SHEE: My answer
to your question
is, yes, I think it is.

OK, what we've seen is a lot
of local providers pivoting

to providing mail
order or delivery, OK.

And those who used the crisis
to unfreeze what they thought

their business model was and
pivoted I think potentially
could do very well, right?

So what the crisis
has also done is

we've seen the impact
on the logistics links
in the supply chains.

OK, so there's been huge
dislocations in that.

In the United States, for
example, what we've seen

is much heavier demand on
trucking for restocking grocery
stores.

OK, and the food and
medical supplies.

At the same time,
where we've seen

a collapse of
demand for trucking
to supply Industrial production.

OK, and normally, that's a very
balanced system where people
arrange back hauls and so on.

But we've made life very
difficult for people

who are trying to supply
the necessities, groceries,
and so on.

We even see, for example,
companies like Amazon
struggling to keep up, OK?

So there's been a lot of
changes that have impacted
the logistics network, OK?

And I always think
about logistics as one
of those unseen things.

Because a lot of the
trucking and the restocking
happens at night.

But it's a really well-tuned
and well-oiled network

which we've thrown out of
kilter with this disruption.

OK, and that's why we're seeing
shortages in stores as people

try to pivot to
the new realities.

You see that among the
commercial food providers,
for example.

Like the Ciscos, who
serve restaurants

and institutional food
service, where suddenly demand
has dried up.

But the materials that they
sell, and it breaks your heart

when you see farmers
saying, there's

nobody buying all this produce,
I'm going to destroy it.

When in reality, you don't
see it in the grocery store.

We've seen that
with milk and so on.

And this is because the
institutional supply chains are

a little different from
the consumer supply chains,

and we've gotten things
out of balance here.

BRIAN KENNY: Now these
are great insights, Willy.

I'm going to hold you
for two more questions,

and then we'll let you
get back to your day.

One of them just keys off
what you were just saying.

We've heard a lot
about disruption

in meat processing
plants, stories coming out

of South Dakota with
the pork industry.

There's been speculation
that we will face shortages
of meat going forward.

I'm not going to ask you to
predict the future on that,

but the question
has to do more with,

how can institutions
prepare for interruptions
that may lie ahead?
WILLY SHEE: Yeah.

I think that's a
critical question.

OK, now, we can
actually look to China

for a lot of these things in
terms of restarting production.

So if it's a packing
plant in the Dakotas

or if it's an auto
company, right, I think--

and the Europeans are starting
to follow the same practices

in terms of cleanliness
and hygiene,
in terms of distancing.

How are we going to
rearrange production lines?

Right, so, I mean, I think
we're going to be in a new era

in terms of how we manage
this type of thing.

My hope is people are
going to give more thought

to the importance of carrying
inventory and safety stock so

that I can survive some
of these disruptions,

especially around
critical commodities.

I visited a factory
a couple years ago.

It was actually
Novo Nordisk factory
in Collin Berg, Denmark.

And they make 50% of the
world's supply of insulin.
OK, and in one factory.
And I talked to them about that.

It's like, how do you
feel about that risk?

And they said, we realize
that we have a responsibility
to be able to provide to people.

Because can you
imagine not being

able to provide half the world's
supply of insulin like that?

They have a five year
stock in the deep freeze

just to protect their
customers, right?

But we're in an era where we've
had some business leaders talk
about inventory is evil, right?

And I understand
why you don't want

to have a lot of inventory,
especially with fashion goods

or things that go obsolete or
the carrying cost of holding
inventories, OK?

But maybe we need to
rethink some of those things

based on the lessons
we've learned here.

BRIAN KENNY: So one last
question that keys off of that

one nicely, which is that
we've got a financial situation

in Wall Street, where
short termism has been

the focus for a long
time, and companies

are expected to
make their numbers

and to be accurate
in their predictions.

Do you see this kind
of thing changing

the way we think about financial
forecasting going forward?
And how the markets operate.

Will they be more lenient,
I guess, is the question,

to firms that are
trying to figure out
how to adapt in this situation?

WILLY SHEE: Well, we can
hope that's the case.

I hate to end on a down note,
but I'm pessimistic about that.

OK, and the reason I'm
pessimistic about that--

I was talking to
somebody about N95 masks.

Now it turns out that I was
buying some last summer,

because I was doing
some dusty work, OK?

So you go to Home Depot and
you go to the paint aisle,
and you can see N95 masks.

Well, in those days, you
could buy them at Home Depot.
You can't anymore.

But the question gets down
to, if you're a consumer

and you see N95 masks that are
higher cost because they are

made locally and there's that
surge capacity to supply you

in an emergency versus one
that costs half as much

that was made in
a low cost country

but otherwise is equivalent,
which one are you going to buy?
OK.

And that's the
problem that is going

to take a lot of rethinking,
how do I get around that?

And so, I'm a little pessimistic
on that, because it reflects,

at the end, it's
price competition that
drives this type of behavior.

I haven't figured out
how we get around that.

BRIAN KENNY: Willy, thanks
so much for the insights
and for the candor.
Great conversation.

WILLY SHEE: Well,
thanks for having me.
